heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction
text:
Let $$\label{eq:BVsys} (H_\theta \Phi)_n = B_{n+1}(\theta)\Phi_{n+1}+ B_n^{(*)}(\theta) \Phi_{n-1}+ V_n (\theta)\Phi_n$$ where $F_n(\theta):=F(\theta+n\omega)$ for any $d\times d$-matrix valued function. We set $B^{(*)}(\theta)=(B(\theta))^*$ for $\theta\in \mathbb T$, and require it to be the analytic extension of $(B(\theta))^*$ off of the real torus. Here $\theta,\omega\in\mathbb{T}^b$ and we assume that $\omega$ is Diophantine, i.e., $$\begin{aligned} \omega\in \mathrm{DC}:=&\bigcup_{a>0, A>b} \mathrm{DC}_{a,A}, \text{ where}\\ \mathrm{DC}_{a,A}=&\left\{\omega\in \mathbb T^b:\, \|k\cdot \omega\|_{\mathbb T^b}\geq \frac{a}{|k|^A}\, \text{ for all } k\in \mathbb Z^d\setminus \{0\}\right\}. \end{aligned}$$ We further assume that $B,V\in C^{\omega}(\mathbb{T}^b_{\eta}, \mathrm{Mat}(d,\mathbb C))$ are analytic, where $$\mathbb T^b_{\eta}:=\{\theta+i\varepsilon:\, \theta\in \mathbb T^b,\, \varepsilon\in \mathbb R^d, \text{ and } |\varepsilon|\leq \eta\}$$with some positive $\eta>0$. We assume throughout the paper that $V$ is Hermitian, and that $B$ is invertible ($\det B(\theta)\neq 0$ for any $\theta\in \mathbb T^b_{\eta}$). The difference equation $H_{\theta} \Phi=E\Phi$ is equivalent to the cocycle $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:M_E} \mathcal{C}&\:: (\theta,\Psi)\in \mathbb{T}^b\times \mathbb C^{2d}\mapsto (\theta+\omega, M_E(\theta)\Psi), \notag \\ \quad M_{E}(\theta) &= \left [ \begin{matrix} ( E-V(\theta))B(\theta)^{-1} & -B^{(*)}(\theta) \\ B(\theta)^{-1} & 0 \end{matrix}\right] \end{aligned}$$ in the sense that for $n\ge1$, $$\mathcal{C}^n (\theta,\Psi)=(\theta+n\omega, M_{n,E}(\theta)\Psi), \quad M_{n,E}(\theta)=\prod_{j=n-1}^0 M_E(\theta+j\omega), \quad \Psi_n:=\binom{B_{n}\Phi_n}{\Phi_{n-1}}$$ satisfies $\Psi_n = M_{n,E} (\theta) \Psi_0$. Since $M_E(\theta)$ is (complex) symplectic, see [def:symp], for $\theta\in \mathbb T^b$, the Lyapunov exponents $\{L_j(\omega,M_E)\}_{j=1}^{2d}$, see definition in [def:LE], satisfy $L_{2d-j}=-L_j$ for $1\le j\le d$. In analogy with we establish localization for $H_0$ under a nonvanishing condition on the Lyapunov exponents.
**Theorem 1**. *Assume that $L_d(\omega,M_E)\ge \gamma>0$ for all $E,\omega$. Then $H_0$ exhibits Anderson localization for almost every $\omega$.*
For a perturbative version of this result see Bourgain-Jitomirskaya  and Klein . Theorem 1 has wide applications since operators in quantum mechanics often appear in block form, in particular when dealing with stacked materials or when not restricted to nearest neighbor hopping. Section 7 includes some examples on stacked and twisted bilayer graphene models. Our next theorem, which can be seen as a generalization of \*Theorem 1.6, concerns arithmetic Anderson localization for long-range scalar-valued Jacobi matrices with potential defined on the one-dimensional torus $\mathbb T$. For the one-dimensional torus, there is another quantity, Avila’s quantized acceleration of the cocycle, which we denote by $\kappa^d(\omega,M_E)$, that plays a crucial role in determining the spectral behavior of the corresponding operator. The acceleration was first introduced by Avila in his global theory paper for $\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb R)$ cocycles, and extended to higher dimensional cocycles in . A characterization of the acceleration, for scalar valued Schrödinger operator $d=1$ and for Diophantine $\omega$, through the zeros of Dirichlet determinants was proved in .

heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction
text:
**Theorem 2**. *Fix any $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$. Suppose $g(\theta)=g(-\theta)$. Then for any $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:Theta_d} \theta\in \Theta_d:=\bigcup_{a'>0, t>1} \Big\{\theta: \|2\theta-n\omega\|_{\mathbb T}\geq \frac{a'}{(1+|n|)^{t}}, \text{\ for any\ \ } n\in d^{-1}\mathbb Z\Big\}, \end{aligned}$$ $\tilde{H}_{\theta}$ is Anderson localized on $\sigma(H_{\theta})\cap \{E: L_d(d^{-1}\omega,A_E)>0, \text{\ and\ } \kappa^d(d^{-1}\omega,A_E)=1\}$.*
As a direct corollary, we obtain the following result that strengthens \*Theorem 1.7 for $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$. In fact, let $$\begin{aligned} (\tilde{H}_{\theta,v,\nu}^{\cos,g}\phi)_n=\sum_{1\leq |k|\leq d}v_k \phi_{n-k}+(2 \cos(2\pi (\theta+nd^{-1}\omega))+\nu \cdot g(\theta+nd^{-1}\omega))\phi_n \end{aligned}$$ be a perturbation of the following operator considered in : $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:operator_HS3} (\tilde{H}^{\cos}_{\theta,v}\phi)_n=\sum_{1\leq |k|\leq d}v_k\phi_{n-k}+2 \cos(2\pi (\theta+nd^{-1}\omega))\phi_n. \end{aligned}$$
**Corollary 3**. *Fix $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$. Suppose $I$ is a closed interval such that $$\inf_{E\in I} L_d(d^{-1}\omega, A^{\cos}_E)\geq \gamma>0,$$ where $A^{\cos}_E$ is the one-step transfer matrix corresponding to the unperturbed operator in [eq:operator_HS3]. Then there exists $\nu_0=\nu_0(\omega,\gamma,v,g)>0$ such that for any $|\nu|\leq \nu_0$, $\tilde{H}^{\cos,g}_{\theta,v,\nu}$ is Anderson localized in $I\cap \sigma(\tilde{H}^{\cos,g}_{\theta,v,\nu})$ for any $\theta\in \Theta_d$.*

heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction
text:
The proof combines the techniques developed in . The special non-perturbed case $\nu=0$ already leads to a proof of a quantitative version of Avila’s almost reducible conjecture for Schrödinger cocycles with trignometric potentials . See also Avila’s proof for the general analytic case. The next theorem also concerns arithmetic Anderson localization, for operators in [eq:BVsys] satisfying certain symmetries.
**Theorem 4**. *Let $H_{\theta}$ be as in [eq:BVsys] on the $1$-d torus $\mathbb T$, and with $B(\theta)\equiv B$ being constant. Suppose there exists an orthonormal matrix $J\in \mathrm{Mat}(d,\mathbb C)$, such that $$\begin{aligned} \label{assume:t2_1} JV(\theta)J^{-1}=V^T(-\theta), \text{ and } JBJ^{-1}=B^T. \end{aligned}$$ Let $f_{E,n}(\theta)$ be the finite volume Dirichlet determinant with periodic boundary conditions, see [def:fn]. Assume further that $f_{E,n}(\theta)$ is $d^{-1}$-periodic, namely, $$\begin{aligned} \label{assume:t2_2} f_{E,n}(\theta+d^{-1})=f_{E,n}(\theta). \end{aligned}$$ Then for $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$ and $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:theta} \theta\in \Theta:=\bigcup_{a'>0, t>1}\left\{\theta: \|2\theta-n\omega\|_{\mathbb T}\geq \frac{a'}{(1+|n|)^t}, \text{ for any } n\in \mathbb Z\right\}, \end{aligned}$$ $H_{\theta}$ is Anderson localized on $\sigma(H_{\theta})\cap \{E:\, \kappa^d(\omega,M_E)\leq 2d-1, \text{ and } L_d(\omega,M_E)>0\}$.*

heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction
text:
**Remark 5**. *Without the assumption [assume:t2_2], one can show that $H_{\theta}$ is Anderson localized on $\sigma(H_{\theta})\cap \{E:\, \kappa^d(\omega,M_E)=1, \text{ and } L_d(\omega,M_E)>0\}$. Note for $E\in \sigma(H_{\theta})$, by \*Lemma 6.4, $0\neq \kappa^d(\omega,M_E)\in \mathbb Z$. By the quantization and upper-semicontinuity of $\kappa^d$, and the arguments in \*p. 80–83, the theorem applies to a set of positive measure of energies or to no energy at all.*
The first application of Theorem 4 concerns a model arising from the study of the anisotropic XY spin chain. We refer the reader to Sec. 6.1 for the connection between the following model and spin chains, and the previous results.

heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction
text:
**Theorem 6**. *Let $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:HXY} (\widetilde{H}^{XY}_{\omega,\theta,\rho,v}\phi)_n=B \phi_{n+1}+V(\theta+n\omega) \phi_n+B^* \phi_{n-1}, \end{aligned}$$ where $\theta,\omega\in \mathbb T$, $\rho\in \mathbb R$ and $$\begin{aligned} B=\left(\begin{matrix}1 &\rho\\ -\rho &-1\end{matrix}\right), \text{ and\ \ } V(\theta)=\left(\begin{matrix} v(\theta) &0 \\ 0 &-v(\theta)\end{matrix}\right). \end{aligned}$$ Here $v$ is an even analytic function satisfying $v(\theta+\frac{1}{2})=-v(\theta)$. Then for any $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$ and $\theta\in \Theta$ as in [def:theta], $\widetilde{H}_{\omega,\theta,\rho,v}^{XY}$ is Anderson localized in $\sigma(\widetilde{H}^{XY}_{\omega,\theta,\rho,v})\cap\{E: \kappa^2(\omega,M_E)\leq 3, \text{ and } L_2(\omega,M_E)>0\}$. In particular, with $v(\theta)=2\lambda\cos(2\pi\theta)$, $\widetilde{H}^{XY}_{\omega,\theta,\rho,2\lambda\cos}$ is Anderson localized in $\{E: L_2(\omega,M_E)>0\}$.*
The next application of Theorem 4 concerns the skew-shift model with rational frequencies.
**Theorem 7**. *For any reduced rational $p/q$, $q\geq 3$ [^1], there exists $\lambda_0=\lambda_0(p/q)>0$ such that the skew-shift operator $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:H_sk} (H^{sk}_{\lambda,x,y,p/q}\phi)_n=\phi_{n+1}+\phi_{n-1}+2\lambda \cos(2\pi(x+ny+n(n-1)p/q))\phi_n,

heading.title: Introduction

section_path: Introduction
text:
**Theorem 7**. *For any reduced rational $p/q$, $q\geq 3$ [^1], there exists $\lambda_0=\lambda_0(p/q)>0$ such that the skew-shift operator $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:H_sk} (H^{sk}_{\lambda,x,y,p/q}\phi)_n=\phi_{n+1}+\phi_{n-1}+2\lambda \cos(2\pi(x+ny+n(n-1)p/q))\phi_n, \end{aligned}$$ has zero Lyapunov exponent for every $y\in \mathrm{DC}$, see [def:LE_sk_y], on the spectrum for $0<|\lambda|< \lambda_0$. The Lyapunov exponent here is averaged in $x\in\mathbb{T}$.*
**Remark 8**. *In \*p. 66, Bourgain suggested that one might be able to combine the large deviation estimates with numerical computations to establish positive Lyapunov exponent for the operator in [def:H_sk] for small $\lambda$ for the Lyapunov exponent averaged in both $x,y\in \mathbb T$. That may be true due to the fact that $\sigma(H^{sk}_{\lambda,x,y,p/q})$ depends sensitively on $y$, and hence any fixed $E\neq 0$ is not in the spectrum of $H^{sk}_{\lambda,x,y,p/q}$ for some $y$.*
The proof of Theorem 7 is built on establishing Anderson localization for the dual model, obtained as a corollary of Theorem 4. We actually prove a stronger almost localization result, see Theorem 53. Combining almost localization with the quantitative duality techniques from , one should be able to prove quantitative almost reducibility of $H^{sk}_{\lambda,x,y,p/q}$ and conclude purely absolutely continuous spectrum for this operator through the perturbative theory of Eliasson . We leave this and other applications of quantitative almost reducibility of this operator for future work.

text:
# Lyapunov exponents, large deviations, and the Green’s function

Throughout, we adhere to the following notations. For a function $g$ on $\mathbb T^b$, we denote its $L^p(\mathbb T^b)$ norm by $\|g\|_{\mathbb T^b, p}$, and we write $\langle g\rangle:=\int_{\mathbb T^b } g(\theta)\, \mathrm{d}\theta$ for averages. For $x\in \mathbb R^d$, let $\|x\|_{\mathbb{T}^b}:=\mathrm{dist}(x,\mathbb Z^d)$ be the distance to the nearest integer vector. Let $\mathcal{C}_1:=\{z\in \mathbb C:\, |z|=1\}$ be the unit circle, and $\mathcal{A}_R:=\{z\in \mathbb C:\, 1/R\leq |z|\leq R\}$. For a set $U\subset\mathbb R^b$, let $\mathrm{mes}(U)$ be its Lebesgue measure. For $\ell\in \mathbb Z$ and $q\in \mathbb N$, let $[\ell]_q\in \{0,...,q-1\}$ be such that $[\ell]_q\equiv \ell\, (\mathrm{mod}\,  q)$. Throughout the paper, we restrict to energy $E\in \mathbb R$.

heading.title: Lyapunov exponents, large deviations, and the Green’s function

section_path: Lyapunov exponents, large deviations, and the Green’s function / Transfer matrices
text: ## Transfer matrices As we mentioned in the introduction, $M_E$ as in [def:M_E] is the transfer matrix associated to the block-valued operator $H_{\theta}$ in [eq:BVsys]. The long-range scalar-valued operator $\tilde{H}_{\theta}$ as in [def:tH] can, on the one hand, be viewed as a $d\times d$ block-valued operator, where the corresponding blocks are $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:tH_BV} &V(\theta)= \left(\begin{matrix} g(\theta+(d-1)d^{-1}\omega) &v_1 &\cdots &v_{d-2} &v_{d-1}\\ \overline{v_1} &g(\theta+(d-2)d^{-1}\omega)&\ddots &\ddots &v_{d-2}\\ \vdots &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &\vdots \\ \overline{v_{d-2}} &\ddots &\ddots &g(\theta+d^{-1}\omega) &v_1\\ \overline{v_{d-1}} &\overline{v}_{d-2} &\cdots &\overline{v_1} &g(\theta) \end{matrix}\right), \text{ and } \\ &\qquad\qquad B= \left(\begin{matrix} \overline{v_d} &\overline{v_{d-1}} &\cdots &\overline{v_2} &\overline{v_1}\\ &\overline{v_d} &\overline{v_{d-1}} &\ddots &\overline{v_2}\\ & &\ddots &\ddots & \vdots \\ & & &\overline{v_d} &\overline{v_{d-1}}\\ & & & &\overline{v_d} \end{matrix}\right) \end{aligned}$$

text:
## Large deviation estimates and the Avalanche Principle We will require the following standard tools. Now $b\ge1$ again. Note that we do not distinguish the various $\delta$’s in the following Lemmas  9, 10 and 13.
**Lemma 9**. *For $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$, there exists $\delta>0$ so that for each $1\leq j\leq d$ and all large $n$, one has $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{n} \log \big \|\textstyle{\bigwedge^j} M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\big\|\leq {L}^{j}_{(n),\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)+ n^{-\delta}, \end{aligned}$$ uniformly in $\theta\in \mathbb{T}^b$ and $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta$, $\varepsilon\in\mathbb R^b$.*
The following large deviation estimates play a crucial role in our argument. These results were first established in Lemma 1.1 of  by Bourgain and Goldstein, and further developed by Goldstein and Schlag in .
**Lemma 10**. *For $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$, there exists $\delta>0$ such that for any $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta$ and $n$ large enough, the following large deviation set $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:badnE} \mathcal{B}_{n,E,\varepsilon}:=\left\{\theta\in\mathbb{T}^b:\, \frac{1}{n}\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge^d} M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\|\leq {L}_{(n),\varepsilon}^d(\omega,M_E)-n^{-\delta}\right\} \end{aligned}$$ satisfies $\mathrm{mes}(\mathcal{B}_{n,E,\varepsilon})\leq e^{-n^\delta}$.*
We will also use the Lipschitz continuity of $L^{d}_{(n),\varepsilon}(\omega,E)$ with respect to $\varepsilon$.

heading.title: Large deviation estimates and the Avalanche Principle

section_path: Lyapunov exponents, large deviations, and the Green’s function / Large deviation estimates and the Avalanche Principle
text:
**Lemma 11**. *\*Corollary 2.12 There exists $C=C(B,V,|E|)>0$, such that for each $1\leq j\leq 2d$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Lip_eps} |L^j_{(n),\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)-L^j_{(n),\varepsilon'}(\omega,M_E)|\leq C\sum_{\ell=1}^b |\varepsilon_\ell-\varepsilon_\ell'|, \end{aligned}$$ for all sufficiently small $|\varepsilon|$, and uniformly in $n$. In particular, the same bound hold with $L^j_{\varepsilon}$ instead of $L^j_{(n),\varepsilon}$.*
By Lemma 11, the Lyapunov exponents are Lipshitz continuous in $\varepsilon$. Since throughout the paper, we work under the condition that $L_d(\omega,M_E)\geq \gamma>0$, we may shrink $\eta$ (depending on $\gamma$) to guarantee $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:L_d>0_varepsilon} \inf_{|\varepsilon|\leq \eta} L_{d,\varepsilon}(\omega, M_E)\geq \frac{1}{2}L_d(\omega,M_E)>0, \text{\ \ and \ \ } \sup_{|\varepsilon|\leq \eta}L_{d,\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)\leq -\frac{1}{2}L_d(\omega,M_E)<0. \end{aligned}$$ The Avalanche Principle was first introduced for $\mathrm{SL}(2,\mathbb R)$ cocycles by Goldstein and Schlag, see . It was extended to larger matrices in .

heading.title: Large deviation estimates and the Avalanche Principle

section_path: Lyapunov exponents, large deviations, and the Green’s function / Large deviation estimates and the Avalanche Principle
text:
**Theorem 12**. *\*Proposition 2.42 Let $m\ge 2$ be fixed. There exist $c_0, C_0>0$ such that for any $0<\varepsilon<1$, $0<\kappa\frac{1}{\kappa}, \text{\ \ for all\ \ } 0\leq j\leq n-1\\ \frac{\|g_j g_{j-1}\|}{\|g_j\| \|g_{j-1}\|}>\varepsilon, \text{\ \ for all\ \ } 1\leq j\leq n-1 \end{aligned}$$ one has $$\begin{aligned} \Big| \log \|g_{n-1}\cdots g_0\|+\sum_{j=1}^{n-2}\log \|g_j\|-\sum_{j=1}^{n-1} \log \|g_j g_{j-1}\|\Big|\leq C_0\, n \frac{\kappa}{\varepsilon^2}. \end{aligned}$$*
The following rate of convergence of $L^d_{(n),\varepsilon}$ to $L^d_{\varepsilon}$ holds, see \*Lemma 10.1.
**Lemma 13**. *Let $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$. Suppose $L_d(\omega,M_E)\geq \gamma>0$, then there exists $\delta>0$ such that for any $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta$ and $n\geq n(\gamma)$, we have $$\begin{aligned} L^d_{\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)\leq L^d_{(n),\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)\leq L^d_{\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)+n^{-\delta}. \end{aligned}$$*
The proof uses the Avalanche principle, which requires the positivity of $L_{d,\varepsilon}(\omega,E)$, provided by [eq:L_d>0_varepsilon].

text:
## Numerator and denominator of the Green’s function Lemma 14 bounds the numerator of the Green’s function, and Lemma 16 the denominator.
**Lemma 14**. *Let $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$. Let $3d\leq y\leq (n-1)d-1$ and $0\leq x\leq d-1$ or $(n-1)d\leq x\leq nd-1$. Set $\ell:=\lfloor y/d\rfloor$. Then for any $\varepsilon>0$, and uniformly in $\theta\in \mathbb T^b$, $$\begin{aligned} |\mu_{n,x,y}(\theta)|\leq C_{d,B} \cdot e^{n(\langle\log |\det B|\rangle+\varepsilon)} \cdot \left(e^{\ell {L}^{d-1}+(n-\ell){L}^d}+e^{\ell {L}^d+(n-\ell){L}^{d-1}}\right), \end{aligned}$$ where $L^j=L^j(\omega,M_E)$, provided $n>N(\varepsilon)$ is large enough. Here $C_{d,B}$ is a constant depending only on $d$ and $\|B^{-1}\|_{\mathbb T^b, \infty}$.*
The proof proceeds as in , see Section 3. The upper bound with $\varepsilon$ suffices to obtain exponential decay of the Green’s function. Regarding the denominator, we first have the following connection between $f_{E,n}$ and the transfer matrix $M_{n,E}$.
**Lemma 15**. *One has pointwise in $\theta\in \mathbb T^b_{\eta}$ that $$\begin{aligned} |f_{E,n}(\theta)|= |\det (M_{n,E}(\theta)-I_{2d})| \cdot \prod_{j=0}^{n-1}|\det B(\theta+j\omega)| . \end{aligned}$$*

heading.title: Numerator and denominator of the Green’s function

section_path: Lyapunov exponents, large deviations, and the Green’s function / Numerator and denominator of the Green’s function
text:
**Lemma 16**. *Let $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$, and $\delta>0$ be as in Lemma 10. Assume $L_d(\omega,M_E)\geq \gamma>0$. There exist $\delta_1\in (0,\delta)$, $N_0>1$ large and $0<\kappa_0\ll 1$ so that the *$\kappa_0$-admissible* sequence $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:admissible} \mathcal{N}:=\{n\geq N_0: \|n\omega\|_{\mathbb{T}^b}\leq \kappa_0\} \end{aligned}$$ has the following property: for any $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta/2$, and all large $\kappa_0$-admissible $n$, the following large deviation set $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:B_fEn} \mathcal{B}_{f,E,n,\varepsilon}:= \big\{\theta\in \mathbb{T}^b: \log |f_{E,n}(\theta+i\varepsilon)|
**Remark 17**. *For every large integer $n>0$ there exists an admissible $\tilde n>0$ with $|n-\tilde n|\le C_*$ for some constant $C_*$.*
The proof is analogous to the denominator bound in , using the original strategy of Proposition 3.3 in . We postpone the proofs of Lemmas 16 and the following corollary to Sec. 4.

heading.title: Numerator and denominator of the Green’s function

section_path: Lyapunov exponents, large deviations, and the Green’s function / Numerator and denominator of the Green’s function
text:
**Lemma 18**. *Under the same conditions as Lemma 16. There exists $\delta_2\in (0,\delta_1)$ such that for any $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta/2$ and large $\kappa_0$-admissible $n$, $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{n} \int_{\mathbb T^b}\log |f_{E,n}(\theta+i\varepsilon)|\, \mathrm{d}\theta\geq L^d_{\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)+\langle \log |\det B(\cdot+i\varepsilon)|\rangle -n^{-\delta_2}. \end{aligned}$$*
This lemma (with $b=1$) will only be used in the proof of arithmetic Anderson localization in Sec.5.2. In view of Lemmas 16 and 18, we will further shrink $\eta$ to $\eta/2$ such that those estimates hold for $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta$. The following pointwise upper bound of $f_{E,n}$, which does not require admissible $n$, complements the preceding lower bound.
**Lemma 19**. *Let $\omega\in \mathrm{DC}$, and $\delta>0$ be as in Lemma 9. For $n$ large enough, we have uniformly in $\theta\in \mathbb T^b$ and $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta$ that $$\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{n}\log |f_{E,n}(\theta+i\varepsilon)|\leq L^d_{\varepsilon}(\omega,M_E)+\langle \log |\det B(\cdot+i\varepsilon)|\rangle+n^{-\delta}. \end{aligned}$$*

heading.title: Bounding the numerator: Lemma 14

section_path: Bounding the numerator: Lemma 14
text: # Bounding the numerator: Lemma 14 We write the monodromy matrices in block form $$\begin{aligned} M_{n,E}(\theta) =\left(\begin{array}{c|c} M_{n,E}^{UL}(\theta) & M_{n,E}^{UR}(\theta) \\ \hline M_{n,E}^{LL}(\theta) & M_{n,E}^{LR}(\theta) \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ where each $M_{n,E}^{\dagger}$ is a $d\times d$ block, $\dagger=UL, UR, LL, LR$. We will make use of the following recursive relations: for $n=1$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:rec1} \begin{cases} M_{1,E}^{UL}(\theta) =-(V(\theta) -E)B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{1,E}^{UR}(\theta) =-B^{(*)}(\theta)\\ M_{1,E}^{LL}(\theta) =B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{1,E}^{LR}(\theta) =0 \end{cases} \end{aligned}$$ and for each $n\geq 2$, one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:rec2} \begin{cases} M_{n,E}^{UL}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{UL}(\theta+\omega) (V(\theta)-E)B^{-1}(\theta)+M_{n-1,E}^{UR}(\theta+\omega) B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{n,E}^{UR}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{UL}(\theta+\omega) B^{(*)}(\theta)\\ M_{n,E}^{LL}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{LL}(\theta+\omega) (V(\theta)-E)B^{-1}(\theta)+M_{n-1,E}^{LR}(\theta+\omega)B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{n,E}^{LR}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{LL}(\theta+\omega) B^{(*)}(\theta) \end{cases} \end{aligned}$$ We now turn to the proof of Lemma 14, which is a straightforward adaption of Section 4 of . We restrict ourselves to the case $0\leq x\leq d-1$ and $3d\leq y\leq (n-1)d-1$. For $(n-1)d\leq x\leq nd-1$, one proceeds analogously, see . With $y=\ell d+r$, $\ell\in [3,n-2]$ and $r\in [0,d-1]$, we let $$\begin{aligned} R_{x,y}:=\left(\begin{array}{c|c} P_n(\theta)-E & {\bf e}_{dn,x}\\ \hline {\bf e}_{dn,y}^{*} & 0 \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ where ${\bf e}_{m,j}^*=(\delta_j(m-1),...,\delta_j(1),\delta_j(0))$. By definition, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:muxy=Rxy} |\mu_{n,x,y}(\theta)|= |\det R_{x,y}| \end{aligned}$$ and, with $V(\theta+j\omega)-E=:C_j$, $B(\theta+j\omega)=:B_j$ and $B^{(*)}(\theta+j\omega)=:B_j^{(*)}$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Rxy} \qquad R_{x,y} = &\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c} C_{n-1} & B_{n-1}^{(*)} & & & & & & &B_0 &\\ \hline B_{n-1} &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & \\ \hline &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & &\\ \hline & &\ddots &\ddots &B_{\ell+1}^{(*)} & & & & &\\ \hline & & & B_{\ell+1} &C_{\ell} &B_\ell^{(*)} & & & &\\ \hline & & & &B_\ell &C_{\ell-1} &\ddots & & &\\ \hline & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & &\\ \hline & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &B_1^{(*)} &\\ \hline B_0^{(*)}& & & & & & &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline & & & &{\bf e}_{d,r}^* & & & & & \end{array}\right) =: \left(\begin{matrix} \mathrm{Row}_1\\ \mathrm{Row}_2\\ \vdots\\ \text{Row}_{n+1} \end{matrix}\right) \end{aligned}$$ Performing the identical row operations as in  we obtain that $|\det R_{x,y}|=|\det R^{(1)}_{x,y}|$ where $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:R(1)} R^{(1)}_{x,y} \!\! =\!\! \left(\!\!\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c} \!\!0 \!\!& 0 &0 &\cdots & & & & &\cdots &\!\!0\!\! \!\!&-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) & \!\!0 \\ \hline \!\!B_{n-1}\!\! &0 &0 &\cdots & & & & &\cdots &\!\!0\!\!\!\! &-M_{n-2}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{n-2}^{UR}(1) & \!\!0 \\ \hline \!\!0\!\!&\!\!B_{n-2} \!\!&\!\!C_{n-3} \!\!&\!\!B_{n-3}^{(*)} \!\!& & & & & & & & &\\ \hline \vdots& &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & &\\ \hline & & & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & &\\ \hline \vdots & & & &\!\!B_{\ell+1} \!\!&\!\!C_{\ell}\!\! &\!\!B_\ell^{(*)}\!\!& & & & & &\\ \hline \!\!0\!\!&\cdots & &\cdots &\!\!0 \!\!&\!\!B_\ell \!\!&\!\!0 \!\!&\!\!0\!\! &\cdots &\!\!0\!\! \!\!&-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) & \!\!0\\ \hline \vdots & & & & &\!\!0 \!\!&\!\!B_{\ell-1}\!\! &\!\!C_{\ell-2} \!\!&\!\!B_{\ell-2}^{(*)} \!\!& & &0 &\!\!0\\ \hline & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & &\vdots &\vdots\!\!\\ \hline \vdots& & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &0 &\vdots\!\!\\ \hline \!\!0\!\!& & & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &B_1^{(*)} &\!\!0\!\!\\ \hline \!\! B_0^{(*)}\!\! &\!\!0 \!\!&\cdots & & & & & &\cdots &\!\!0 \!\!\!\!&B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\!\!\\ \hline \!\!0\!\! &\cdots & &\cdots &\!\! 0 \!\!&\!\!{\bf e}_{d,r}^*\!\! & \!\!0\!\! &\cdots & &\cdots & 0 & 0 & \!\!0 \end{array}\!\!\right) \end{aligned}$$ where $M_{k,E}(\theta+j\omega)=:M_k(j)$. By inspection, rows $1$, $2$, $n-\ell+1$, $n$, and $n+1$ are $$\begin{aligned} \left(\begin{matrix} \text{Row}_1^{(n-2)}\\ \text{Row}_2^{(n-3)}\\ \text{Row}_{n-\ell+1}^{(\ell-2)}\\ \text{Row}_{n}\\ \text{Row}_{n+1} \end{matrix} \right) =\left(\begin{array}{ccccccccccc} 0 &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &\cdots &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &\cdots &0 &-M_{n-2}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{n-2}^{UR}(1) &0\\ 0 &0 &\cdots &0 &B_\ell &0 &\cdots &0 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &\cdots &0 &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &0 &\cdots &0 &{\bf e}_{d,r}^* &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ in which only columns $1$, $n-\ell$, $n-1$, $n$, $n+1$ are non-vanishing. Define $$\begin{aligned} S_1:=\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &-M_{n-2}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{n-2}^{UR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right) \end{aligned}$$ as a $(4d+1)\times (4d+1)$ submatrix of rows $1$, $2$, $n-\ell+1$, $n$ and $n+1$. It is unique with the property that any other $(4d+1)\times (4d+1)$ submatrix of these rows has vanishing determinant. Let $$\begin{aligned} S_2:= \left(\begin{array}{cccccccccccccccc} B_{n-2} &C_{n-3} &B_{n-3}^{(*)} & & & & & & & & & & & & &\\ &B_{n-3} &C_{n-4} &\ddots & & & & & & & & & & & &\\ & &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & & & & & &\\ \\ & & & & &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & & &\\ & & & & &\ddots &C_{\ell+2} &B_{\ell+2}^{(*)} & & & & & & & &\\ & & & & & &B_{\ell+2} &C_{\ell+1} &0 & & & & & & &\\ & & & & & & &B_{\ell+1} &B_{\ell}^{(*)} &0 & & & & & &\\ & & & & & & & &B_{\ell-1} &C_{\ell-2} &B_{\ell-2}^{(*)} & & & & &\\ & & & & & & & & &B_{\ell-2} &\ddots &\ddots & & & &\\ & & & & & & & & & &\ddots & & & & &\\ \\ & & & & & & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &\\ & & & & & & & & & & & & &B_4 &C_3 &B_3^{(*)}\\ & & & & & & & & & & & & & &B_3 &C_2 \\ & & & & & & & & & & & & & & &B_2 \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ which is the submatrix of $R^{(1)}_{x,y}$ obtained by deleting rows $1$, $2$, $n-\ell+1$, $n$, $n+1$ and columns $1$, $n-\ell$, $n-1$, $n$, $n+1$. Hence $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:num1} |\det R^{(1)}_{x,y}|= |\det S_1|\cdot |\det S_2|= |\det S_1| \cdot \prod_{\substack{j=2\\ j\ne\ell}}^{n-2}|\det B_j|, \end{aligned}$$ We simplify $$\begin{aligned} \notag |\det S_1|= &\left|\det\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &-M_{n-1}^{LL}(1)B_1 &-B_{n-1}M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right| \notag\\ = &|\det B_1|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1) &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &-B_{n-1}M_{n-1}^{LL}(1) &-B_{n-1}M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1) &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &I_d &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right|\notag

heading.title: Bounding the numerator: Lemma 14

section_path: Bounding the numerator: Lemma 14
text: We write the monodromy matrices in block form $$\begin{aligned} M_{n,E}(\theta) =\left(\begin{array}{c|c} M_{n,E}^{UL}(\theta) & M_{n,E}^{UR}(\theta) \\ \hline M_{n,E}^{LL}(\theta) & M_{n,E}^{LR}(\theta) \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ where each $M_{n,E}^{\dagger}$ is a $d\times d$ block, $\dagger=UL, UR, LL, LR$. We will make use of the following recursive relations: for $n=1$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:rec1} \begin{cases} M_{1,E}^{UL}(\theta) =-(V(\theta) -E)B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{1,E}^{UR}(\theta) =-B^{(*)}(\theta)\\ M_{1,E}^{LL}(\theta) =B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{1,E}^{LR}(\theta) =0 \end{cases} \end{aligned}$$ and for each $n\geq 2$, one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:rec2} \begin{cases} M_{n,E}^{UL}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{UL}(\theta+\omega) (V(\theta)-E)B^{-1}(\theta)+M_{n-1,E}^{UR}(\theta+\omega) B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{n,E}^{UR}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{UL}(\theta+\omega) B^{(*)}(\theta)\\ M_{n,E}^{LL}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{LL}(\theta+\omega) (V(\theta)-E)B^{-1}(\theta)+M_{n-1,E}^{LR}(\theta+\omega)B^{-1}(\theta)\\ M_{n,E}^{LR}(\theta)=-M_{n-1,E}^{LL}(\theta+\omega) B^{(*)}(\theta) \end{cases} \end{aligned}$$ We now turn to the proof of Lemma 14, which is a straightforward adaption of Section 4 of . We restrict ourselves to the case $0\leq x\leq d-1$ and $3d\leq y\leq (n-1)d-1$. For $(n-1)d\leq x\leq nd-1$, one proceeds analogously, see . With $y=\ell d+r$, $\ell\in [3,n-2]$ and $r\in [0,d-1]$, we let $$\begin{aligned} R_{x,y}:=\left(\begin{array}{c|c} P_n(\theta)-E & {\bf e}_{dn,x}\\ \hline {\bf e}_{dn,y}^{*} & 0 \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ where ${\bf e}_{m,j}^*=(\delta_j(m-1),...,\delta_j(1),\delta_j(0))$. By definition, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:muxy=Rxy} |\mu_{n,x,y}(\theta)|= |\det R_{x,y}| \end{aligned}$$ and, with $V(\theta+j\omega)-E=:C_j$, $B(\theta+j\omega)=:B_j$ and $B^{(*)}(\theta+j\omega)=:B_j^{(*)}$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Rxy} \qquad R_{x,y} = &\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c} C_{n-1} & B_{n-1}^{(*)} & & & & & & &B_0 &\\ \hline B_{n-1} &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & \\ \hline &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & &\\ \hline & &\ddots &\ddots &B_{\ell+1}^{(*)} & & & & &\\ \hline & & & B_{\ell+1} &C_{\ell} &B_\ell^{(*)} & & & &\\ \hline & & & &B_\ell &C_{\ell-1} &\ddots & & &\\ \hline & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & &\\ \hline & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &B_1^{(*)} &\\ \hline B_0^{(*)}& & & & & & &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline & & & &{\bf e}_{d,r}^* & & & & & \end{array}\right) =: \left(\begin{matrix} \mathrm{Row}_1\\ \mathrm{Row}_2\\ \vdots\\ \text{Row}_{n+1} \end{matrix}\right) \end{aligned}$$ Performing the identical row operations as in  we obtain that $|\det R_{x,y}|=|\det R^{(1)}_{x,y}|$ where $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:R(1)} R^{(1)}_{x,y} \!\! =\!\! \left(\!\!\begin{array}{c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|c} \!\!0 \!\!& 0 &0 &\cdots & & & & &\cdots &\!\!0\!\! \!\!&-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) & \!\!0 \\ \hline \!\!B_{n-1}\!\! &0 &0 &\cdots & & & & &\cdots &\!\!0\!\!\!\! &-M_{n-2}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{n-2}^{UR}(1) & \!\!0 \\ \hline \!\!0\!\!&\!\!B_{n-2} \!\!&\!\!C_{n-3} \!\!&\!\!B_{n-3}^{(*)} \!\!& & & & & & & & &\\ \hline \vdots& &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & &\\ \hline & & & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & &\\ \hline \vdots & & & &\!\!B_{\ell+1} \!\!&\!\!C_{\ell}\!\! &\!\!B_\ell^{(*)}\!\!& & & & & &\\ \hline \!\!0\!\!&\cdots & &\cdots &\!\!0 \!\!&\!\!B_\ell \!\!&\!\!0 \!\!&\!\!0\!\! &\cdots &\!\!0\!\! \!\!&-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) & \!\!0\\ \hline \vdots & & & & &\!\!0 \!\!&\!\!B_{\ell-1}\!\! &\!\!C_{\ell-2} \!\!&\!\!B_{\ell-2}^{(*)} \!\!& & &0 &\!\!0\\ \hline & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots & &\vdots &\vdots\!\!\\ \hline \vdots& & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &0 &\vdots\!\!\\ \hline \!\!0\!\!& & & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &B_1^{(*)} &\!\!0\!\!\\ \hline \!\! B_0^{(*)}\!\! &\!\!0 \!\!&\cdots & & & & & &\cdots &\!\!0 \!\!\!\!&B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\!\!\\ \hline \!\!0\!\! &\cdots & &\cdots &\!\! 0 \!\!&\!\!{\bf e}_{d,r}^*\!\! & \!\!0\!\! &\cdots & &\cdots & 0 & 0 & \!\!0 \end{array}\!\!\right) \end{aligned}$$ where $M_{k,E}(\theta+j\omega)=:M_k(j)$. By inspection, rows $1$, $2$, $n-\ell+1$, $n$, and $n+1$ are $$\begin{aligned} \left(\begin{matrix} \text{Row}_1^{(n-2)}\\ \text{Row}_2^{(n-3)}\\ \text{Row}_{n-\ell+1}^{(\ell-2)}\\ \text{Row}_{n}\\ \text{Row}_{n+1} \end{matrix} \right) =\left(\begin{array}{ccccccccccc} 0 &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &\cdots &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &\cdots &0 &-M_{n-2}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{n-2}^{UR}(1) &0\\ 0 &0 &\cdots &0 &B_\ell &0 &\cdots &0 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &\cdots &0 &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &0 &\cdots &0 &{\bf e}_{d,r}^* &0 &\cdots &0 &0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ in which only columns $1$, $n-\ell$, $n-1$, $n$, $n+1$ are non-vanishing. Define $$\begin{aligned} S_1:=\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &-M_{n-2}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{n-2}^{UR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right) \end{aligned}$$ as a $(4d+1)\times (4d+1)$ submatrix of rows $1$, $2$, $n-\ell+1$, $n$ and $n+1$. It is unique with the property that any other $(4d+1)\times (4d+1)$ submatrix of these rows has vanishing determinant. Let $$\begin{aligned} S_2:= \left(\begin{array}{cccccccccccccccc} B_{n-2} &C_{n-3} &B_{n-3}^{(*)} & & & & & & & & & & & & &\\ &B_{n-3} &C_{n-4} &\ddots & & & & & & & & & & & &\\ & &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & & & & & &\\ \\ & & & & &\ddots &\ddots & & & & & & & & &\\ & & & & &\ddots &C_{\ell+2} &B_{\ell+2}^{(*)} & & & & & & & &\\ & & & & & &B_{\ell+2} &C_{\ell+1} &0 & & & & & & &\\ & & & & & & &B_{\ell+1} &B_{\ell}^{(*)} &0 & & & & & &\\ & & & & & & & &B_{\ell-1} &C_{\ell-2} &B_{\ell-2}^{(*)} & & & & &\\ & & & & & & & & &B_{\ell-2} &\ddots &\ddots & & & &\\ & & & & & & & & & &\ddots & & & & &\\ \\ & & & & & & & & & & & &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &\\ & & & & & & & & & & & & &B_4 &C_3 &B_3^{(*)}\\ & & & & & & & & & & & & & &B_3 &C_2 \\ & & & & & & & & & & & & & & &B_2 \end{array}\right), \end{aligned}$$ which is the submatrix of $R^{(1)}_{x,y}$ obtained by deleting rows $1$, $2$, $n-\ell+1$, $n$, $n+1$ and columns $1$, $n-\ell$, $n-1$, $n$, $n+1$. Hence $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:num1} |\det R^{(1)}_{x,y}|= |\det S_1|\cdot |\det S_2|= |\det S_1| \cdot \prod_{\substack{j=2\\ j\ne\ell}}^{n-2}|\det B_j|, \end{aligned}$$ We simplify $$\begin{aligned} \notag |\det S_1|= &\left|\det\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &-M_{n-1}^{LL}(1)B_1 &-B_{n-1}M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1)B_1 &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &B_1 &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right| \notag\\ = &|\det B_1|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1) &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_{n-1} &0 &-B_{n-1}M_{n-1}^{LL}(1) &-B_{n-1}M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1) &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ B_0^{(*)} &0 &I_d &C_0 &{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right|\notag \end{aligned}$$ Pulling out the matrices in the first column, we may further simplify this in the form $$\begin{aligned} |\det S_1| = &|\det B_0^{(*)}| |\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1) &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ I_d &0 &- M_{n-1}^{LL}(1) &- M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1) &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ I_d &0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1} & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}C_0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right|\notag \\ = &|\det B_0^{(*)}| |\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{cccccc} 0& 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1) &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ 0& I_d &0 &- M_{n-1}^{LL}(1) &- M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0& 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1) &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ I_d &0 &0 &0 &-B_0 &0\\ 0& I_d &0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1} & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}C_0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0& 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right|\notag \\ =&|\det B_0^{(*)}| |\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c} \left(\begin{matrix}0& 0\\ 0 &I_d\end{matrix}\right)& &\left(\begin{matrix}0 & B_0\\ 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right)-M_{n-1}(1) &\\ \hline & B_{\ell} &-M_{\ell-1}^U(1) & \\ \hline I_{2d} & &-M_1^{-1}(0) &\left(\begin{matrix}0\\ I_d\end{matrix}\right) (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & & \end{array}\right)\right|\notag\\ =&\frac{|\det B_0^{(*)}|}{|\det M_1(0)|} |\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c} \left(\begin{matrix}0& 0\\ 0 &I_d\end{matrix}\right)& &\left(\begin{matrix}I_d & 0\\ 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right)-M_{n}(0) &\\ \hline & B_{\ell} &-(I_d,\, 0) M_{\ell}(0) & \\ \hline I_{2d} & &-I_{2d} &\left(\begin{matrix}0\\ I_d\end{matrix}\right) (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & & \end{array}\right)\right|\notag\\ =&|\det B_0||\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c} \left(\begin{matrix}0& 0\\ 0 &I_d\end{matrix}\right)& &\left(\begin{matrix}I_d & 0\\ 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right)-M_{n}(0) &\\ \hline & B_{\ell} &-(I_d,\, 0) M_{\ell}(0) & \\ \hline I_{2d} & &-I_{2d} &\left(\begin{matrix}0\\ I_d\end{matrix}\right) (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & & \end{array}\right)\right|\notag

\left|\det\left(\begin{array}{ccccc} 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1) &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ I_d &0 &- M_{n-1}^{LL}(1) &- M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1) &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ I_d &0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1} & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}C_0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right|\notag \\ = &|\det B_0^{(*)}| |\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{cccccc} 0& 0 &0 &-M_{n-1}^{UL}(1) &B_0-M_{n-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ 0& I_d &0 &- M_{n-1}^{LL}(1) &- M_{n-1}^{LR}(1) &0\\ 0& 0 &B_\ell &-M_{\ell-1}^{UL}(1) &-M_{\ell-1}^{UR}(1) &0\\ I_d &0 &0 &0 &-B_0 &0\\ 0& I_d &0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1} & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}C_0 & (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ 0& 0 &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & 0 &0 &0 \end{array}\right)\right|\notag \\ =&|\det B_0^{(*)}| |\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c} \left(\begin{matrix}0& 0\\ 0 &I_d\end{matrix}\right)& &\left(\begin{matrix}0 & B_0\\ 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right)-M_{n-1}(1) &\\ \hline & B_{\ell} &-M_{\ell-1}^U(1) & \\ \hline I_{2d} & &-M_1^{-1}(0) &\left(\begin{matrix}0\\ I_d\end{matrix}\right) (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & & \end{array}\right)\right|\notag\\ =&\frac{|\det B_0^{(*)}|}{|\det M_1(0)|} |\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c} \left(\begin{matrix}0& 0\\ 0 &I_d\end{matrix}\right)& &\left(\begin{matrix}I_d & 0\\ 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right)-M_{n}(0) &\\ \hline & B_{\ell} &-(I_d,\, 0) M_{\ell}(0) & \\ \hline I_{2d} & &-I_{2d} &\left(\begin{matrix}0\\ I_d\end{matrix}\right) (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & & \end{array}\right)\right|\notag\\ =&|\det B_0||\det B_1||\det B_{n-1}|\cdot \left|\det\left(\begin{array}{c|c|c|c} \left(\begin{matrix}0& 0\\ 0 &I_d\end{matrix}\right)& &\left(\begin{matrix}I_d & 0\\ 0 & 0\end{matrix}\right)-M_{n}(0) &\\ \hline & B_{\ell} &-(I_d,\, 0) M_{\ell}(0) & \\ \hline I_{2d} & &-I_{2d} &\left(\begin{matrix}0\\ I_d\end{matrix}\right) (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline &{\bf e}^*_{d,r} & & \end{array}\right)\right|\notag \end{aligned}$$ As in , this can now be rewritten in the form $$\label{eq:detS1B} |\det S_1|= |\det (B_0B_1B_\ell B_{n-1})| \biggl|\det\biggl(\begin{array}{c|c} -M_n(0)+I_{2d} &-\left(\begin{matrix}0\\ I_d\end{matrix}\right) (B_0^{(*)})^{-1}{\bf e}_{d,x}\\ \hline {\bf e}_{d,r}^*B_\ell^{-1}(I_d, 0)\cdot M_{\ell}(0) &0 \end{array}\biggr)\biggr|$$ At this point we proceed as for the upper bound on $|\det S_3^{(3)}|$ in Section 4 of . This leads to the following, note $B_0^{(*)}=(B_0)^*$ for $\theta\in \mathbb T^b$: $$\begin{aligned} |\mu_{n,x,y}| &\le C_d \|B^{-1}\|_\infty^2 \prod_{j=0}^{n-1}|\det B_j| \cdot \sum_{m_0} \|\textstyle{\bigwedge^j}^{m_0} M_{\ell}(0)\|\cdot \|\textstyle{\bigwedge^j}^{m_0-1} M_{n-\ell}(\ell)\| \end{aligned}$$ Combining this with Lemma 9 proves the claimed result.

text:
As a preparation for the proof of Lemma 16, we first prove the following. Recall that $n$ is $\kappa_0$-admissible if $\|n\omega\|_{\mathbb{T}^b}\leq \kappa_0$.
**Lemma 20**. *Assume $L_d(\omega,M_E)\geq \gamma>0$. There exists $0<\kappa_0\ll1$ and $\delta_3\in (0,\delta)$ so that for any $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta/2$ and $\kappa_0$-admissible sufficiently large $n$, we have $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:meas_tBn} \mathrm{mes}(\tilde{\mathcal{B}}_{n,E,\varepsilon}):=\mathrm{mes}\Big(\Big\{\theta\in\mathbb{T}^b:\, \Big|\frac{1}{2n}\log\|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{n,E}^2(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|- {L}^d_{\varepsilon}(\omega, M_E)\Big|>n^{-\delta_3}\Big\}\Big)\leq e^{-n^{\delta_3}} \end{aligned}$$*

heading.title: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19

section_path: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19
text: *Proof.* This is essentially \*Lemma 3.2, with minor modifications for higher dimensional monodromy matrices (see the more recent \*Lemma 5.3 for details). The proof follows by induction from the large deviation estimates in Lemmas 9, 10 and the Avalanche principle of Theorem 12, together with Cartan-type bounds in higher dimensions. We briefly sketch the induction below. Let $N_0$ be large enough so that the uniform upper bound (Lemma 9) and large deviation estimate (Lemma 10) hold for any $n\geq N_0$ and $|\varepsilon|\leq 3\eta/4$. Then there exists (see e.g. ) $\kappa_0=\kappa_0(N_0)$ such that for any $|\varepsilon|\leq \eta/2$, $|\kappa|\leq \kappa_0$, and any $\theta$ such that $$\begin{aligned} \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{2N_0,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\geq e^{2N_0L^d_{\varepsilon}-N_0^{1-\delta}}, \end{aligned}$$ we have $$\begin{aligned} \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_0\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_0,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\geq e^{2N_0L^d_{\varepsilon}-2N_0^{1-\delta}}. \end{aligned}$$ This, together with the large deviation Lemma 10 with $n=2N_0$, implies the following

heading.title: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19

section_path: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19
text: **Lemma 21**. *For $|\kappa|\leq \kappa_0$, one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:induction_N0} \mathrm{mes}\left(\left\{\theta\in \mathbb T^b: \left|\frac{1}{2N_0}\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_0\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_0,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|-L^d_{\varepsilon}\right|>N_0^{-\delta}\right\}\right)\leq e^{-N_0^{\delta}}. \end{aligned}$$*

heading.title: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19

section_path: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19
text: Next, consider any $N_1$ such that $4N_0+1\leq N_1\leq e^{N_0^{\delta/2}}$. For any such $N_1$, we decompose $N_1=\ell_1 N_0+r_0$, $N_0\leq r_0<2N_0$, $$\begin{aligned} &\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d\left(M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\\ =&\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d\Big(M_{r_0,E}(\theta+(N_1+\ell_1 N_0)\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)(\prod_{k=\ell_1-1}^{1} M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1+kN_0)\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon))\cdot.\\ &\qquad\cdot M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1-N_0)\omega+i\varepsilon)\\ &.\qquad\cdot (\prod_{j=\ell_1-2}^{0} M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(jN_0+r_0)\omega+i\varepsilon))M_{r_0,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\Big). \end{aligned}$$ By Lemma 21 applied to the product of the middle two matrices, and Lemma 10 and Theorem 12, one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:MN1=MN0} &\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d\left(M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\\ &\qquad\qquad-\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)\|-\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\|\notag\\ =&\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1-N_0)\omega+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\\ &\qquad\qquad -\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\notag\\ &\qquad\qquad -\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1-N_0)\omega+i\varepsilon)\right)\|+O(e^{-\frac{N_0}{2}L_d}) \end{aligned}$$ for $\theta\in \mathcal{B}_1$ where $\mathrm{mes}(\mathcal{B}_1)\leq e^{-N_0^{\delta}/2}$. Clearly, [eq:MN1=MN0] implies that for $\theta\in \mathcal{B}_1$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:LDT_MN1_before} u_{N_1,\kappa}(\theta+i\varepsilon):=\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\geq 2N_1L^d_{\varepsilon}-3N_1^{1-\delta}. \end{aligned}$$ We recall the following Cartan estimate for several variables:

heading.title: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19

section_path: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19
text:
Next, consider any $N_1$ such that $4N_0+1\leq N_1\leq e^{N_0^{\delta/2}}$. For any such $N_1$, we decompose $N_1=\ell_1 N_0+r_0$, $N_0\leq r_0<2N_0$, $$\begin{aligned} &\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d\left(M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\\ =&\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d\Big(M_{r_0,E}(\theta+(N_1+\ell_1 N_0)\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)(\prod_{k=\ell_1-1}^{1} M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1+kN_0)\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon))\cdot.\\ &\qquad\cdot M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1-N_0)\omega+i\varepsilon)\\ &.\qquad\cdot (\prod_{j=\ell_1-2}^{0} M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(jN_0+r_0)\omega+i\varepsilon))M_{r_0,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\Big). \end{aligned}$$ By Lemma 21 applied to the product of the middle two matrices, and Lemma 10 and Theorem 12, one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:MN1=MN0} &\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d\left(M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\\ &\qquad\qquad-\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)\|-\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\|\notag\\ =&\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1-N_0)\omega+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\\ &\qquad\qquad -\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\notag\\ &\qquad\qquad -\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_0,E}(\theta+(N_1-N_0)\omega+i\varepsilon)\right)\|+O(e^{-\frac{N_0}{2}L_d}) \end{aligned}$$ for $\theta\in \mathcal{B}_1$ where $\mathrm{mes}(\mathcal{B}_1)\leq e^{-N_0^{\delta}/2}$. Clearly, [eq:MN1=MN0] implies that for $\theta\in \mathcal{B}_1$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:LDT_MN1_before} u_{N_1,\kappa}(\theta+i\varepsilon):=\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\right)\|\geq 2N_1L^d_{\varepsilon}-3N_1^{1-\delta}. \end{aligned}$$ We recall the following Cartan estimate for several variables:
**Lemma 22**. *\*Lemma 2.15 Let $\varphi(z_1,...,z_b)$ be an analytic function defined on a polydisck $\mathcal{P}=\prod_{j=1}^b \mathcal{D}(z_{j,0},1)$, $z_{j,0}\in \mathbb C$. Let $K\geq \sup_{z\in \mathcal{P}}\log |\varphi(z)|$, $m\leq \log |\varphi(z_0)|$, $z_0=(z_{1,0},...,z_{b,0})$. Given $H\gg 1$ there exists a set $\mathcal{B}\subset \mathcal{P}$, $\mathrm{mes}_{\mathbb R^b}(\mathcal{B}\cap \mathbb R^b)\leq C_b e^{-H}$, such that $$\begin{aligned} \log |\varphi(z)|>K-C_b H(K-m) \end{aligned}$$ for any $z\in \frac{1}{6}\mathcal{P}\setminus \mathcal{B}$.*
**Remark 23**. *In the lemma above, we omitted the definition of Cartan sets, and instead only state the measure estimate.*

heading.title: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19

section_path: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19
text: Note that [eq:LDT_MN1_before] provides us with a lower bound for $u_{N_1,\kappa}$, up to a set of measure $e^{-N_0^{\delta}/2}$, needed in the Cartan estimate. We still need an uniform upper bound in a neighborhood of $\mathbb T^b$. Applying Lemmas 9 and 13 to the cocycle $(\omega, M_E(\cdot+i\varepsilon+i\varepsilon'))$, implies uniformly in $\theta$ that $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:MM_upper1} \sup_{|\varepsilon'|\leq N_1^{-1}}\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon+i\varepsilon')\| \leq &N_1 \sup_{|\varepsilon'|\leq N_1^{-1}} L^d_{\varepsilon+\varepsilon'}+N_1^{1-\delta}\notag\\ \leq &N_1 (L^d_{\varepsilon}+Cb N_1^{-1})+N_1^{1-\delta}, \end{aligned}$$ where we used by Lemma 11 that for $|\varepsilon'|\leq N_1^{-1}$, $$|L^d_{\varepsilon+\varepsilon'}-L^d_{\varepsilon}|\leq CbN_1^{-1}.$$ Clearly, [eq:MM_upper1] implies $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:MM_upper2} \sup_{|\varepsilon'|\leq N_1^{-1}}\log \|\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d \left(M_{N_1,E}(\theta+N_1\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon+i\varepsilon') M_{N_1,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon+i\varepsilon')\right)\| \leq 2N_1 L^d_{\varepsilon}+3N_1^{1-\delta}. \end{aligned}$$ We then have an upper bound of size $2N_1L^d_{\varepsilon}+3N_1^{1-\delta}$ for $u_{N_1,\kappa}(\theta+i\varepsilon)$ needed for the Cartan estimate. Applying Lemma 22 with $K_1=2N_1L^d_{\varepsilon}+3N_1^{1-\delta}$, $m_1=2N_1L^d_{\varepsilon}-3N_1^{1-\delta}$ and $H_1=N_1^{\delta/2}$ (we actually cover $\mathbb T^b$ by polydisks with radius $N_1^{-1}$, and apply Cartan to each of the polydisk. Note that $N_1^{-1}>e^{-N_0^{\delta}/2}$ hence within each such polydisk there is a lower bound $m_1$), we have the following.

text:
**Lemma 25**. *For any $|\kappa|\leq \kappa_0$ and any $N_{j+1}$ such that $4N_j\leq N_{j+1}\leq e^{N_j^{\delta/4}}$, the following holds $$\begin{aligned} \mathrm{mes}\left(\left\{\theta\in \mathbb T^b: u_{N_{j+1},\kappa}(\theta+i\varepsilon)<2N_{j+1}L^d_{\varepsilon}-C_b N_{j+1}^{1-\frac{\delta}{2}}\right\}\right)0$ depending on $b$ only.*
Finally, taking $n$ to be sufficiently large and $\kappa_0$-admissible and $\kappa=-n\omega$ yields the claimed result for $M_{n,E}^2(\theta+i\varepsilon)=M_{n,E}(\theta+n\omega+\kappa+i\varepsilon)M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)$. ◻ Next, we prove Lemma 16
*Proof of Lemma 16.* The proof is the essentially same as that of . We briefly sketch it below. Let $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:M=WDV} M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)=W_n(\theta+i\varepsilon)D_n(\theta+i\varepsilon)V_n^*(\theta+i\varepsilon) \end{aligned}$$ be the singular value decomposition of $M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon)$ as in [eq:Mn_singular_decom]. Let $\theta\in (\mathcal{B}_{n,E,\varepsilon}\cup \tilde{\mathcal{B}}_{n,E,\varepsilon})^c$. We first show

heading.title: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19

section_path: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19
text: **Lemma 26**. *Let $\kappa_0$ be as in Lemma 20. For $n$ large enough, one has for $\theta\in (\tilde{\mathcal{B}}_{n,E,\varepsilon})^c$ that $$\begin{aligned} &|\langle v_{1}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\textstyle{\bigwedge}\cdots \textstyle{\bigwedge} v_{d}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon), w_{1}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\textstyle{\bigwedge}\cdots \textstyle{\bigwedge} w_{d}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\rangle|\\ =&|\det (\langle v_{j}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon), w_{k}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\rangle)_{1\leq j,k\leq d}|\geq e^{-6n^{1-\delta_3}}. \end{aligned}$$*

heading.title: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19

section_path: Bounding the denominator: Lemmas  15, 16, 18 and 19
text: *Proof.* Towards a contradiction, suppose that for some $\theta\in (\tilde{\mathcal{B}}_{n,E,\varepsilon})^c$ one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:assume_a1-d_small} |\det (\langle v_{j}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon), w_{k}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\rangle)_{1\leq j,k\leq d}|\leq e^{-6n^{1-\delta_3}}. \end{aligned}$$ For any $1\leq m_1<...[eq:assume_a1-d_small], one has $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:a1-d} |a_{1,...,d}^{1,...,d}(\theta+i\varepsilon)|\leq e^{-6n^{1-\delta_3}}. \end{aligned}$$

text:
By Lemmas 9, 13, and estimates [eq:prod_sigma_1], [eq:prod_sigma_2], [eq:prod_sigma_3], [eq:aj1-jd_trivial], [eq:a1-d], one has for $n$ large enough, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:M2_v1-d} \qquad &\|(\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d M_{n,E}^2(\theta+i\varepsilon)) (v_{1}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\textstyle{\bigwedge} \cdots \textstyle{\bigwedge} v_{d}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\|\notag\\ =&\prod_{j=1}^d \sigma_j(M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\cdot \|(\textstyle{\bigwedge}^d M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon) (w_{1}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\textstyle{\bigwedge}\cdots \textstyle{\bigwedge} w_{d}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\| \notag\\ \leq &e^{n(L^d_{\varepsilon}+2n^{-\delta})} \sum_{1\leq j_1<...[eq:M2_v1-d] with [eq:M2_vm1-md], we arrive at a contradiction with $\theta\in (\tilde{\mathcal{B}}_{n,E,\varepsilon})^c$. ◻ Lemma 26 implies
**Corollary 27**. *Let $\kappa_0$ be as in Lemma 20. For $n$ large enough, we have for $\theta\in (\mathcal{B}_{n,E,\varepsilon}\cup \tilde{\mathcal{B}}_{n,E,\varepsilon})^c$ that $$\begin{aligned} &|\langle v_{d+1}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\textstyle{\bigwedge}\cdots \textstyle{\bigwedge} v_{2d}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon), w_{d+1}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\textstyle{\bigwedge}\cdots \textstyle{\bigwedge} w_{2d}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\rangle|\\ =&|\det (\langle v_{d+j}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon), w_{d+k}^{(n)}(\theta+i\varepsilon)\rangle)_{1\leq j,k\leq d}|\geq e^{-6n^{1-\delta_3}}. \end{aligned}$$*
Since the proof is exactly the same as that of , we shall not repeat it here. Now we are in position to complete the proof of Lemma 16.

text: *Proof.* Let $\theta\in(\mathcal{B}_{n,E,\varepsilon}\cup\tilde\mathcal{B}_{n,E,\varepsilon})^c$. We estimate $|\det(M_{n,E}(\theta)-I_{2d})|$ as in [eq:M=DWV] using Schur’s lemma. Let $D_n=D_n(\theta+i\varepsilon)$ be as in [eq:M=WDV] and $Q_n=Q_n(\theta+i\varepsilon)$ be as in [eq:WV=Q], and write (omitting $\theta+i\varepsilon$ below for simplicity) $$\begin{aligned} Q_n= \left(\begin{matrix} Q_1 & Q_2\\ Q_3 & Q_4 \end{matrix}\right), \text{ and } D_n=\left(\begin{matrix} D_1 & 0\\ 0 & D_4 \end{matrix}\right). \end{aligned}$$ where each block is of size $d\times d$. By Schur’s lemma, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schur_0} |\det (D_n-Q_n)| =& |\det (D_1-Q_1)|\cdot |\det (D_4-Q_4-Q_3(D_1-Q_1)^{-1}Q_2)|\notag\\ =&|\det (D_1-Q_1)|\cdot |\det (D_4-Q_4)|\cdot |\det (I_d-(D_4-Q_4)^{-1}Q_3(D_1-Q_1)^{-1}Q_2)|. \end{aligned}$$ Since $\theta\in \mathcal{B}_{n,E,\varepsilon}^c$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schur_1} \prod_{j=1}^d \sigma_j(M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\geq e^{n(L^d_{\varepsilon}-n^{-\delta})}. \end{aligned}$$ By Lemma 9 and that $L^{d-1}_{(n),\varepsilon}\leq L^{d-1}_{\varepsilon}+\nu$ for arbitrary small $0<\nu\ll L_d$ and $n$ large, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schur_2} \prod_{j=1}^{d-1}\sigma_j(M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\leq e^{n(L^{d-1}_{\varepsilon}+\nu)}. \end{aligned}$$ Combining [eq:Schur_1] with [eq:Schur_2], we conclude that $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schur_22} \min_{j=1\ldots d} \sigma_j(M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\geq \sigma_d (M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\geq e^{n(L_{d,\varepsilon}-2\nu)}. \end{aligned}$$ Similarly, by Lemma 9 applied to $L^{d+1}$, $$\begin{aligned} \prod_{j=1}^{d+1}\sigma_j(M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\leq e^{n(L^{d+1}_{\varepsilon}+\nu)}, \end{aligned}$$ which implies, analogously to [eq:Schur_22], that $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schur_23} \max_{j=d+1\ldots 2d}\sigma_j(M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\leq \sigma_{d+1}(M_{n,E}(\theta+i\varepsilon))\leq e^{n(L_{d+1,\varepsilon}+2\nu)}. \end{aligned}$$ Recall that by [eq:L_d>0_varepsilon], $$\begin{aligned} L_{d+1,\varepsilon}<-\frac{1}{2}L_d<0<\frac{1}{2}L_d[eq:Schur_1], [eq:Schur_22] and $\|Q_1\|\leq 1$ (see [eq:Q<1]), yields $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schur_3} |\det (D_1-Q_1)|\geq e^{n(L^d_{\varepsilon}-2n^{-\delta})}, \text{ and } \|(D_1-Q_1)^{-1}\|\leq e^{-n(L_{d,\varepsilon}-3\nu)}. \end{aligned}$$ Recall that by Corollary 27, $|\det Q_4|\geq e^{-6n^{1-\delta_3}}$, and hence $\|Q_4^{-1}\|\leq C_d e^{6n^{1-\delta_3}}$. Since by [eq:Schur_23] that $\|D_4\|\leq e^{n(L_{d+1,\varepsilon}+2\nu)}$, we have $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schur_4} |\det (D_4-Q_4)|\geq e^{-7n^{1-\delta_3}}, \text{ and } \|(D_4-Q_4)^{-1}\|\leq C_d e^{7n^{1-\delta_3}}. \end{aligned}$$ Combining [eq:Schur_3], [eq:Schur_4] with $\|Q_2\|+\|Q_3\|\leq 1$, we infer by [eq:Schur_0], $$\begin{aligned} |\det(D_n-Q_n)|\geq e^{n(L^d_{\varepsilon}-10 n^{-\delta_3})}, \end{aligned}$$ as claimed. ◻

text: # Localization

heading.title: Localization

section_path: Localization / Proof of Theorem 1: nonarithmetic localization
text:
## Proof of Theorem 1: nonarithmetic localization The following result does not require $n$ to be $\kappa_0$-admissible.
**Corollary 28**. *Let $\omega\in DC_{a,A}$ and assume $L_d(E,M_E)\geq \gamma>0$. For $n\ge n_0(a,A,b, \gamma, B,V)$, there exists a set $\mathcal{S}_n(E,\omega)\subset\mathbb{T}^b$ with the property that $\mathrm{mes}(\mathcal{S}_n(E,\omega))<\exp(-n^\delta)$ with $\delta=\delta(a,A)>0$ and $$\label{eq:GregE} |G_{E,n}(\theta;x,y)|\le \exp(-|x-y|\cdot L_d+n^{1-\delta})$$ for all $x,y\in [0,dn-1]$ and all $\theta\in\mathbb{T}^b\setminus\mathcal{S}_n(E,\omega)$.*
*Proof.* First consider the case $0\le x \le d-1$ or $(n-1)d\leq x\leq nd-1$, and $n$ is $\kappa_0$-admissible. Then the claim follows from Lemmas 14 and 16, together with the elementary fact $$\log \prod_{j=0}^{n-1}|\det B_j(\theta)| = n \langle \log |\det B|\rangle + O(n^{1-\delta})$$ which can be proved via Fourier series. To remove the restriction that $x$ is located near the edges of $[0,dn-1]$, as well as the admissibility condition, we pave $[0,dn-1]$ with intervals of sizes about $n^{\frac12 }$, say, which are $\kappa_0$-admissible. Iterating the resolvent identity with these smaller intervals as in \*Lemma 2.2 then yields the desired statement, with possibly smaller $\delta$. ◻
The localization theorem can now be proved via the well-known Bourgain, Goldstein strategy  and \*Chapter 10. The main steps are as follows:

heading.title: Proof of Theorem 1: nonarithmetic localization

section_path: Localization / Proof of Theorem 1: nonarithmetic localization
text:
The localization theorem can now be proved via the well-known Bourgain, Goldstein strategy  and \*Chapter 10. The main steps are as follows:

1.  Eliminate the energy. This involves a quantitative Seidenberg-Tarski theorem in the theory of semi-algebraic sets.

2.  Eliminate $\omega\in\mathbb{T}^b$ that may lead to double resonances, uniformly in the energy.

3.  Starting from Shnol’s theorem, and using absence of double resonances, show exponential localization.

The key step (b) is based on the idea that $\omega$ (the “slow variable") and $N\omega$ (the “fast variable") resemble independent random variables in $\mathbb{T}$, but only when measured on sets consisting of $m\ll N$ intervals. The latter condition is the reason that semi-algebraic sets enter into the analysis in a crucial and quantitative fashion. We will rely on \*Chapter 9 for the technical statements about semi-algebraic theory, in particular on Corollary 9.7 and Lemma 9.9 in loc. cit. However, we would like to point out that the Yomdin parametrization of Theorem 9.4 with quantitative polynomial bounds, which is needed in these results, was erroneously attributed to Gromov’s work during the mid 1980s. In fact, these essential polynomial bounds were finally established by Binyamini and Novikov , thus closing a gap in  that had remained open for almost 15 years.

heading.title: Proof of Theorem 1: nonarithmetic localization

section_path: Localization / Proof of Theorem 1: nonarithmetic localization
text: The key step (b) is based on the idea that $\omega$ (the “slow variable") and $N\omega$ (the “fast variable") resemble independent random variables in $\mathbb{T}$, but only when measured on sets consisting of $m\ll N$ intervals. The latter condition is the reason that semi-algebraic sets enter into the analysis in a crucial and quantitative fashion. We will rely on \*Chapter 9 for the technical statements about semi-algebraic theory, in particular on Corollary 9.7 and Lemma 9.9 in loc. cit. However, we would like to point out that the Yomdin parametrization of Theorem 9.4 with quantitative polynomial bounds, which is needed in these results, was erroneously attributed to Gromov’s work during the mid 1980s. In fact, these essential polynomial bounds were finally established by Binyamini and Novikov , thus closing a gap in  that had remained open for almost 15 years. To begin the localization proof, we start from a solution $H_0\Phi=E\Phi$ with $|\Phi_0|+|\Phi_1|>0$ and $|\Phi_n|\le C_\Phi(1+|n|)$ for all $n\in\mathbb Z$. The latter is the folklore Shnol’s theorem, see e.g. \*Theorem 2.1 for a self-contained derivation. Arguing as in \*(10.7), (10.8) we see that we may cover the set $\mathcal{S}_n(E,\omega)$ by a semi-algebraic set $\widetilde\mathcal{S}_n(E,\omega)$ of polynomial degree $O(n^{p})$ in all the variables $(\theta, E,\omega)\in \mathbb{T}^b\times\mathbb R\times DC_{A,a}$, and of similar measure. In this step, one uses that the Diophantine condition $\|k\cdot\omega\|\ge a|k|^{-A}$ is only needed in the range $0<|k|\le n^{C_A}$ for Lemma 16 to hold (see \*page 859). We denote this finite volume Diophantine condition by $DC_{a,A}(n)$.

## Arithmetic Anderson localization This section restricts to the case of a one-dimensional torus $\mathbb T$ and constant $B(\theta)\equiv B$. We follow the strategy of to show the large deviation set $\mathcal{B}_{f,E,n}:=\mathcal{B}_{f,E,n,0}$ as in [def:B_fEn] can be covered by roughly $2\kappa^d(\omega,M_E)\cdot n$ many intervals of small length, and then use a Pigeon-hole principle argument to eliminate double resonances. The number $2\kappa^d(\omega,M_E)\cdot n$ arises from the number of zeros of $f_{E,n}(z)$, with the identification $z=e^{2\pi i\theta}$, in a thin annulus containing $\mathcal{C}_1$. The zeros of $f_{E,n}(z)$ off the unit circle form pairs, as can be seen from the following fact.
**Lemma 29**. *For any $n$ and $\theta\in \mathbb T$, $f_{E,n}(\theta)=\overline{f_{E,n}(\theta)}$.*
*Proof.* $$\begin{aligned} &\overline{f_{E,n}(\theta)}\\ &=\det \left(\begin{matrix} V(\theta+(n-1)\omega)-E & B^* & & &B\\ B &V(\theta+(n-2)\omega)-E &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B^*\\ B^* & & &B &V(\theta)-E \end{matrix}\right)^*\\ &=\det \left(\begin{matrix} V^*(\theta+(n-1)\omega)-E & B^* & & &B\\ B &V^*(\theta+(n-2)\omega)-E &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B^*\\ B^* & & &B &V^*(\theta)-E \end{matrix}\right)\\ &=f_{E,n}(\theta), \end{aligned}$$ where we used $V^*=V$. ◻

text:
Lemma 29 implies the two holomorphic function $f_{E,n}(z)$ and $\overline{f_{E,n}(1/\overline{z})}$ coincide on the unit circle $z\in \mathcal{C}_1$. Hence $f_{E,n}(z)=\overline{f_{E,n}(1/\overline{z})}$ on $\mathcal{A}_{e^{2\pi\eta}}$. This implies
**Fact 30**. *If $w\in \mathcal{A}_{e^{2\pi\eta}}\setminus \mathcal{C}_1$ is a zero of $f_{E,n}(z)$, then $1/\overline{w}$ is also a zero.*
Next, we recall the Green’s function on an annulus, which is standard.
**Lemma 31**. *The Green’s function on the annulus $\mathcal{A}_R$ satisfies $$\begin{aligned} G_R(z,w) &= \frac{1}{2\pi}\log |z-w| + H_R(z,w), \quad z\in \mathcal{A}_R, w\in \overline{\mathcal{A}_R} \label{def:Green_annulus} \\ \Delta_z H_R (z,w) &= 0 \nonumber \end{aligned}$$ The Green’s function is symmetric and invariant under rotations: $G_R(z,w)=G_R(w,z)$ and $G_R(z,w)=G_R(e^{i\phi} z,e^{i\phi} w)$, for any $\phi\in \mathbb R$.*
We also recall the integral of the Green’s function along a circle.
**Lemma 32**. *For $1/R\leq r\leq R$ and $w\in \mathcal{A}_R$, we have $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:int_Green} I(\log r, \log R, w) &:=2\pi \int_0^{1} G_R (re^{ 2\pi i\theta}, w)\, \mathrm{d}\theta \\ & =(2\log R)^{-1} \begin{cases} \log (rR) \log|w/R|, \text{ if } |w|\geq r\\ \\ \log( r/ R) \log |w R|, \text{ if } |w| We now turn to the basic Riesz representation of subharmonic functions.

heading.title: Arithmetic Anderson localization

section_path: Localization / Arithmetic Anderson localization
text:
**Lemma 33**. *Let $v$ be a subharmonic function in a neighborhood of $\overline{\mathcal{A}_R}$, and assume $v|_{\partial \mathcal{A}_R}$ is a continuous function. Let $G_R$ be the Green’s function for $\mathcal{A}_R$, as in [def:Green_annulus]. There exists a positive finite measure $\mu$ on $\mathcal{A}_R$, and a harmonic function $h_R$ on $\mathcal{A}_R$, such that $$\begin{aligned} v(w)=\int_{\mathcal{A}_R} 2\pi G_R(z,w)\, \mu(\mathrm{d}z)+h_R(w), \end{aligned}$$ where $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Poisson} h_R(w)=\int_{\partial \mathcal{A}_R} v(z)\,\nu(w,\mathcal{A}_R)( \mathrm{d}z), \end{aligned}$$ where $\nu(w,\mathcal{A}_R)$ is the harmonic measure of $\mathcal{A}_R$ with pole at $w$. In particular, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:h=v} h_R(z)=v(z), \text{ for } z\in \partial \mathcal{A}_R. \end{aligned}$$*
**Remark 34**. *By the maximum principle, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:max_h} \sup_{w\in \mathcal{A}_R} h_R(w)\leq \max_{z\in \partial \mathcal{A}_R} v(z). \end{aligned}$$*

## Proof of Theorem 2 It suffices to show that each generalized eigenfunction $u$, satisfying $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Schnol} \max(|u_0|, |u_1|)=1, \text{ and } |u_k|\leq C|k|, \text{ for all } k\neq 0, \end{aligned}$$ decays exponentially. Note that under the assumption that $\kappa^d(d^{-1}\omega, A_E)=1$, by [eq:M=A] we conclude that $\kappa^d(\omega,M_E)=d\cdot \kappa^d(d^{-1}\omega,A_E)=d$. Hence by Theorem 35, $N_n(E,\eta/3)\leq 2n(d+\nu)$. We first show in this setting, there is an additional symmetry that reduce the number of zeros of $f_{E,n}(z)$ from at most $2n(d+\nu)$ to no more than $n(d+\nu)$ pairs. The following lemma is essential.
**Lemma 36**. *For the operator $\tilde{H}_{\theta}$ as in Theorem 2, we have $$f_{E,n}(\theta-\frac{nd-1}{2d}\omega)=\overline{f_{E,n}(-\theta-\frac{nd-1}{2d}\omega)}.$$*
*Proof.* We first establish the following property of the matrix potential $V$ and coefficient matrix $B$ from [def:tH_BV].
**Lemma 37**. *For matrix $J$ as in [def:J] below, one has $JV(\theta-\frac{d-1}{2d}\omega)J^{-1}=V^T(-\theta-\frac{d-1}{2d}\omega)$ and $JBJ^{-1}=B^T$.*

heading.title: Proof of Theorem 2

section_path: Localization / Proof of Theorem 2
text: *Proof.* In the following, we write $g(\theta,m):=g(\theta+md^{-1}\omega)$ for simplicity. Recall that $B,V$ are as in [def:tH_BV]. Let $$\begin{aligned} \label{def:J} J=\left(\begin{matrix} & & & &1\\ & & &1 &\\ & &\udots & &\\ &1 & & &\\ 1 & & & & \end{matrix}\right)_{d\times d} \end{aligned}$$ We have $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:JVJ=V} JV(\theta-\frac{d-1}{2d}\omega)J^{-1} =& J\left(\begin{matrix} g(\theta,\frac{d-1}{2}) &v_1 &\cdots &v_{d-2} &v_{d-1}\\ \overline{v_1} &g(\theta,\frac{d-3}{2})&\ddots &\ddots &v_{d-2}\\ \vdots &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &\vdots \\ \overline{v_{d-2}} &\ddots &\ddots &g(\theta,-\frac{d-3}{2}) &v_1\\ \overline{v_{d-1}} &\overline{v_{d-2}} &\cdots &\overline{v_1} &g(\theta,-\frac{d-1}{2}) \end{matrix}\right)J^{-1}\notag\\ =&\left(\begin{matrix} g(\theta,-\frac{d-1}{2}) &\overline{v_1} &\cdots &\overline{v_{d-2}} &\overline{v_{d-1}}\\ v_1 &g(\theta,-\frac{d-3}{2}) &\ddots &\ddots &\overline{v_{d-2}}\\ \vdots &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &\vdots \\ v_{d-2} &\ddots &\ddots &g(\theta,\frac{d-3}{2})&\overline{v_1}\\ v_{d-1} &v_{d-2} &\cdots &v_1 &g(\theta,\frac{d-1}{2}) \end{matrix}\right) \notag\\ =&\left(\begin{matrix} g(-\theta,\frac{d-1}{2}) &\overline{v_1} &... &\overline{v_{d-2}} &\overline{v_{d-1}}\\ v_1 &g(-\theta,\frac{d-3}{2}) &\ddots &\ddots &\overline{v_{d-2}}\\ \vdots &\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &\vdots \\ v_{d-2} &\ddots &\ddots &g(-\theta,-\frac{d-3}{2})&\overline{v_1}\\ v_{d-1} &v_{d-2} &\cdots &v_1 &g(-\theta,-\frac{d-1}{2}) \end{matrix}\right) \\ =&V^T(-\theta-\frac{d-1}{2d}\omega) \notag \end{aligned}$$ To pass to [eq:JVJ=V] we used that $g$ is even. It is also easy to check that $$\begin{aligned} JBJ^{-1} =\left(\begin{matrix} \overline{v_d} & & & &\\ \overline{v_{d-1}} &\ddots & &\\ \vdots &\ddots &\ddots & & \\ \overline{v_2}&\ddots &\ddots &\ddots &\\ \overline{v_1} &\overline{v_2} &\cdots &\overline{v_{d-1}} &\overline{v_d} \end{matrix}\right)=B^T. \end{aligned}$$ Hence we have proved the claimed identities. ◻

text: *Proof.* Argue by contradiction. Suppose there exists $\ell_1\in I_1$ such that $$\theta+\ell_1\alpha\notin \bigcup_{j=1}^{N}(U_j\cup (-(nd-1)d^{-1}\omega-U_j)).$$ By Lemma 39, it is necessary that $\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega\notin \widetilde{\mathcal{B}}_{f,n,E}$, which implies $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:u_I1_large} \frac{1}{n}\log |f_{E,n}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega)|\geq L^d+\log |\det B|-n^{-\delta_1/2}. \end{aligned}$$ Let $\ell_2:=\ell_1+nd-1$. By Lemma 14, for any $\varepsilon_1>0$, we see that for $n$ large enough, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Dk_upper} &\sup_{m\in \{0,...,d-1\}}\max(\log |\mu_{n,m,-\ell_1}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega)|, \log |\mu_{n,nd-1-m,-\ell_1}(\theta+\ell_1 d^{-1}\omega)|)\\ &\qquad\qquad \leq n\cdot \log |\det B|+\max(-[\ell_1d^{-1}] L^{d-1}+[\ell_2d^{-1}] L^d, -[\ell_1d^{-1}] L^d+[\ell_2d^{-1}] L^{d-1})+n\varepsilon_1 \end{aligned}$$ This implies by [eq:mufn] that for any $m\in \{0,...,d-1\}$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:Green_I1} |G_{E,n}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega; -\ell_1, m)|=&\frac{|\mu_{n,m,-\ell_1}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega)|}{|f_{E,n}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega)|}\leq \max(e^{[\ell_1d^{-1}]L_d}, e^{-[\ell_2d^{-1}] L_d})\cdot e^{n\varepsilon_1}\\ |G_{E,n}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega; -\ell_1, nd-1-m)=&\frac{|\mu_{n,nd-1-m,-\ell_1}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega)|}{|f_{E,n}(\theta+\ell_1d^{-1}\omega)|}\leq \max(e^{[\ell_1d^{-1}] L_d}, e^{-[\ell_2d^{-1}] L_d})\cdot e^{n\varepsilon_1}. \end{aligned}$$ Combining the above with [eq:Poisson_exp] and [eq:Schnol], we have $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:phi0} |u_0| \leq C\sum_{k\in \{0,...,d-1\}\cup \{(n-1)d,...,nd-1\}}\max(e^{[\ell_1d^{-1}] L_d}, e^{-[\ell_2d^{-1}] L_d})\cdot e^{n\varepsilon_1} \cdot (nd) \leq e^{-\frac{1}{10} n L_d}. \end{aligned}$$ invoking $\min(|\ell_1|, |\ell_2|)\geq [nd/8]$. Similarly, one shows that $|u_1|<1/2$. Hence we arrive at a contradiction with the assumption that $\max(|u_0|, |u_1|)=1$. ◻

## Proof of Theorem 4 Recall that we assumed that there exists an orthonormal matrix $J$, such that $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:JVJ=Vt_JBJ=Bt} JV(\theta)J^{-1}=V^T(-\theta), \text{ and } JBJ^{-1}=B^T. \end{aligned}$$ First, we prove a lemma which is analogous to Lemma 36.
**Lemma 44**. *We have $$f_{E,n}(\theta-\frac{n-1}{2}\omega)=\overline{f_{E,n}(-\theta-\frac{n-1}{2}\omega)}.$$*

heading.title: Proof of Theorem 4

section_path: Localization / Proof of Theorem 4
text: *Proof.* We calculate (recall that $V(\theta,k):=V(\theta+k\omega)-E$) $$\begin{aligned} &f_{E,n}(\theta-\frac{n-1}{2}\omega)\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} V(\theta,\frac{n-1}{2}) & B^* & & &B\\ B &V(\theta,\frac{n-3}{2}) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B^*\\ B^* & & &B &V(\theta,-\frac{n-1}{2}) \end{matrix}\right)\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} V(\theta,-\frac{n-1}{2}) & B & & &B^*\\ B^* &V(\theta,-\frac{n-3}{2}) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B\\ B & & &B^* &V(\theta,\frac{n-1}{2}) \end{matrix}\right)\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} JV(\theta,-\frac{n-1}{2})J^{-1} & JBJ^{-1} & & &JB^*J^{-1}\\ JB^*J^{-1} &JV(\theta,-\frac{n-3}{2})J^{-1} &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &JBJ^{-1}\\ JBJ^{-1} & & &JB^*J^{-1} &JV(\theta,\frac{n-1}{2})J^{-1} \end{matrix}\right) \end{aligned}$$ This can further be simplified in the form $$\begin{aligned} \notag &f_{E,n}(\theta-\frac{n-1}{2}\omega)\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} V^T(-\theta,\frac{n-1}{2}) & B^T & & &\overline{B}\\ \overline{B} &V^T(-\theta,\frac{n-3}{2}) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B\\ B^T & & &\overline{B} &V^T(-\theta,-\frac{n-1}{2}) \end{matrix}\right)\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} \overline{V(-\theta,\frac{n-1}{2})} & \overline{B^*} & & &\overline{B}\\ \overline{B} &\overline{V(-\theta,\frac{n-3}{2})} &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &\overline{B^*}\\ \overline{B^*} & & &\overline{B} &\overline{V(-\theta,-\frac{n-1}{2})} \end{matrix}\right)\\ =&\overline{f_{E,n}(-\theta-\frac{n-1}{2}\omega)}, \end{aligned}$$ in which we used $V^*(\theta)=V(\theta)$. ◻

text:
## Anisotropic XY spin chain model in quasi-periodic magnetic fields

The XY-chain model is an exactly solvable model, first understood in by Lieb-Schultz-Mattis, due to the fact that the Jordan-Wigner transformation maps the XY-chain Hamiltonian to a Hamiltonian of free Fermions. Since then the XY-chain has become a prototypical model in understanding phenomena in many-body quantum theory.

heading.title: Proof of Theorem 6

section_path: Applications to spin chains and the skew shift / Anisotropic XY spin chain model in quasi-periodic magnetic fields / Proof of Theorem 6
text: ### Proof of Theorem 6 We obtain Theorem 6 as a corollary of Theorem 4. It suffices to check the conditions [assume:t2_1] and [assume:t2_2]. Let $J$ be the following orthonormal matrix: $$\begin{aligned} J=\left(\begin{matrix} 1 & 0\\ 0 &-1\end{matrix}\right). \end{aligned}$$ Clearly $JV(\theta)J^{-1}=V^T(-\theta)$, where we used $v$ is even, and $JBJ^{-1}=B^T$, which verifies [assume:t2_1] of Theorem 4. Next, let us verify $f_{E,n}(\theta)=f_{E,n}(\theta+\frac{1}{2})$ for even $n$. It is easy to see that for $$\begin{aligned} L=\left(\begin{matrix}0 & 1\\ 1 & 0\end{matrix}\right) \end{aligned}$$ we have $$\begin{aligned} L(V(\theta+\frac{1}{2})-E)L^{-1}=\left(\begin{matrix} -v(\theta+\frac{1}{2})-E &0\\ 0&v(\theta+\frac{1}{2})-E\end{matrix}\right)=V(\theta)-E, \end{aligned}$$ where we used the assumption that $v(\theta+\frac{1}{2})=-v(\theta)$. It is also straightforward to check $LBL^{-1}=-B$. Hence, with $V_E(\theta,j):=V(\theta+j\omega)-E$, one has $$\begin{aligned} &f_{E,n}(\theta+\frac{1}{2})\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} V_E(\theta+\frac{1}{2},n-1) & B^* & & &B\\ B &V_E(\theta+\frac{1}{2},n-2) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B^*\\ B^* & & &B &V_E(\theta+\frac{1}{2},0) \end{matrix}\right)\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} LV_E(\theta+\frac{1}{2},n-1)L^{-1} & LB^*L^{-1} & & &LBL^{-1}\\ LBL^{-1} &LV_E(\theta+\frac{1}{2},n-2)L^{-1} &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &LB^*L^{-1}\\ LB^*L^{-1} & & &LBL^{-1} &LV_E(\theta+\frac{1}{2},0)L^{-1} \end{matrix}\right)\\ =& \det\left(\begin{matrix} V_E(\theta,n-1) & -B^* & & &-B\\ -B &V(\theta,n-2) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &-B^*\\ -B^* & & &-B &V_E(\theta,0) \end{matrix}\right). \end{aligned}$$ Finally we remove the minus signs in front of $B$ and $B^*$ via conjugating the matrix by (only possible for even $n$) $$\mathrm{diag}(I_2, -I_2, I_2, -I_2,..., I_2, -I_2)_{2n\times 2n}.$$ Hence $$\begin{aligned} f_{E,n}(\theta+\frac{1}{2})=\det\left(\begin{matrix} V_E(\theta,n-1) & B^* & & &B\\ B &V_E(\theta,n-2) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B^*\\ B^* & & &B &V_E(\theta,0) \end{matrix}\right) =f_{E,n}(\theta). \end{aligned}$$ This verifies the assumption [assume:t2_2] of Theorem 4 (for even $n$ only; hence one needs to further restrict the admissible sequence to even numbers. However, this is still a sequence of positive density, thus does not affect the proof of localization). Hence Theorem 4 implies Theorem 6 as a corollary. 0◻

**Definition 1** (Resonances of $\theta$). *Let $y,\theta\in \mathbb T$ and $\varepsilon>0$. We say $k\in \mathbb Z$ is an $\varepsilon$-resonance of $\theta$ if $\|q\cdot (2\theta-ky)\|_{\mathbb T}\leq e^{-|k|^{\varepsilon}}$ and $\|q\cdot (2\theta-ky)\|_{\mathbb T}=\min_{|j|\leq k} \|q\cdot (2\theta-jy)\|_{\mathbb T}$.*
In the rest of the section, we fix some $\varepsilon$ such that $0<\varepsilon<\delta_1/4$, where $\delta_1>0$ is as in Lemma 47.
**Definition 2**. *Let $0=|n_0|\leq |n_1|\leq |n_2|\leq ...$ be the $\varepsilon$-resonances of $\theta$. If this sequence is infinite, we say $\theta$ is $\varepsilon$-resonant, otherwise we say it is $\varepsilon$-non-resonant. Furthermore, if $\theta$ is $\varepsilon$-non-resonant with a finite sequence of resonances $0=|n_0|\leq |n_1|\leq ...\leq |n_j|$, we let $n_{j+1}=\infty$.*
**Remark 52**. *If $y\in \mathrm{DC}_{a,A}$ for some $a>0$ and $A>1$, then for $j$ large enough, one has $$|n_{j+1}|>q^{-1} C_{a,A}\cdot e^{A^{-1}|n_j|^{\varepsilon}}.$$ Indeed by triangle inequality, we have $$\begin{aligned} e^{-|n_j|^{\varepsilon}}\geq \|q (2\theta-n_jy)\|_{\mathbb T} \geq &\|q(n_j-n_{j+1})y\|_{\mathbb T}-\|q (2\theta-n_{j+1}y)\|_{\mathbb T}\\ \geq &\frac{a}{|q(n_j-n_{j+1})|^A}-e^{-|n_{j+1}|^{\varepsilon}}, \end{aligned}$$ implying the claimed inequality.*

**Theorem 53**. *There exists a constant $C_2>0$ such that for any $y\in \mathrm{DC}$, $\{\widehat{H}_{\lambda,\theta,y,p/q}\}_{\theta\in \mathbb T}$ is $(5, C_2, L_q(\omega,M_E)/(10q))$-almost localized in $\{E: L_q(\omega,M_E)>0\}$.*

text: *Proof.* We first check the conditions [assume:t2_1] and [assume:t2_2] of Theorem 4 are satisfied and that for $E\in \sigma(\widehat{H}_{\lambda,\theta,y,p/q})\cap \{E: L_q(\omega,M_E)>0\}$, $$\begin{aligned} \label{eq:kappa_q=q} \kappa^q(\omega,M_E)\leq q. \end{aligned}$$ Note this provides a tighter upper bound than the required $2q-1$ as in Theorem 4. It is easy to compute that as $\varepsilon\to\infty$, $L^q_\varepsilon(\omega,M_E)=2\pi q\varepsilon+o(1)$, hence $\kappa^q_\varepsilon(\omega,M_E)=q$ for $\varepsilon$ large enough. Convexity of $L^q_\varepsilon(\omega,M_E)$ in $\varepsilon$ implies $\kappa^q(\omega,M_E)\leq q$, which verifies [eq:kappa_q=q]. Next, we turn to [assume:t2_1], which follow directly from $V(-\theta)=V^T(\theta)$ and $B=B^T$.

Thus, with $V_E(\theta,j):=V(\theta+j\omega)-E$, $$\begin{aligned} &f_{E,n}(\theta+\frac{1}{q})\\ &= \det\left(\begin{matrix} V_E(\theta+\frac{1}{q},n-1) & B^* & & &B\\ B &V_E(\theta+\frac{1}{q},n-2) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B^*\\ B^* & & &B &V_E(\theta+\frac{1}{q},0) \end{matrix}\right)\\ &= \det\left(\begin{matrix} LV_E(\theta+\frac{1}{q},n-1)L^{-1} & LB^*L^{-1} & & &LBL^{-1}\\ LBL^{-1} &LV_E(\theta+\frac{1}{q},n-2)L^{-1} &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &LB^*L^{-1}\\ LB^*L^{-1} & & &LBL^{-1} &LV_E(\theta+\frac{1}{q},0)L^{-1} \end{matrix}\right)\\ &= \det\left(\begin{matrix} V_E(\theta,n-1) & B^* & & &B\\ B &V_E(\theta,n-2) &\ddots \\ & \ddots &\ddots &\ddots \\ & &\ddots &\ddots &B^*\\ B^* & & &B &V_E(\theta,0) \end{matrix}\right)\\ &=f_{E,n}(\theta). \end{aligned}$$ Thus assumption [assume:t2_2] of Theorem 4 holds with $d=q$. Indeed, we have
**Lemma 54**. *Let $y\in \mathrm{DC}_{a,A}$ for some $a>0$ and $A>1$. Let $\kappa_0>0$ be as in Lemma 16, and $C_*>0$ be the constant as in Remark 17. Let $\widetilde{\mathcal{B}}_{f,E,n}^{(2)}$ be as in [def:BfEn^(2)]. For $j$ large enough, and for $z$ such that $5(1+|n_j|) The principle for choosing $I_1, I_2$ is to guarantee [eq:I_1+I_2_neq_nj] holds. We will prove this lemma in details. text: *Proof.* Towards a contradiction, suppose $\theta+\ell\omega\in \widetilde{\mathcal{B}}_{f,E,n}^{(2)}$ for any $\ell\in I_1\cup I_2$. Clearly $|I_1|+|I_2|>\frac{9}{8}n-C$, for some absolute constant $C>0$. Also since $\kappa^q\leq q$ (see [eq:kappa_q=q]), which is a tighter upper bound than $2q-1$, Lemma 47 implies $N\leq n(1+\varepsilon_1)$ for $\varepsilon_1\in (0,1/10)$. Since $|I_1|+|I_2|>N$, by the Pigeon hole principle, there exists $1\leq j\leq N$ and $\ell_1,\ell_2\in I_1\cup I_2$ such that $$\begin{aligned} \{\theta+\ell_1 y, \theta+\ell_2 y\}\subset \left(\bigcup_{m_1=1}^q (U_j+m_1/q)\right)\cup \left(\bigcup_{m_2=1}^q (-U_j-(n-1)y+m_2/q)\right) \end{aligned}$$
